From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


American comedy film
Dating and New YorkTheatrical release posterDirected byJonah FeingoldWritten byJonah FeingoldProduced byJoaquin AcrichStarring
Jaboukie Young-White
Francesca Reale
Catherine Cohen

CinematographyMaria RuscheEdited byHanna A. ParkMusic byGrant FondaProductioncompany

Distributed byIFC FilmsRelease dates
June 13, 2021 (2021-06-13) (Tribeca)
September 10, 2021 (2021-09-10) (United States)
Running time91 minutes[1]CountryUnited StatesLanguageEnglishBox office$47,215[2][3]
Dating and New York is a 2021 American comedy film written and directed by Jonah Feingold in his directorial debut. It stars Jaboukie Young-White, Francesca Reale, Catherine Cohen, Brian Muller, Jerry Ferrara, Arturo Castro, Taylor Hill, Alex Moffat, Eva Victor and Yedoye Travis.
It had its world premiere at Tribeca Film Festival on June 13, 2021. It was released on September 10, 2021 by IFC Films.


Cast[edit]

Jaboukie Young-White as Milo
Francesca Reale as Wendy
Catherine Cohen as Jessie
Brian Muller as Hank
Jerry Ferrara as Cole
Arturo Castro
Taylor Hill as Olivia
Jonah Feingold as Mort
Alex Moffat as Trent
Eva Victor
Yedoye Travis as Tripp
Production[edit]
In December 2019, it was announced Jaboukie Young-White, Francesca Reale, Catherine Cohen, Brian Muller, Jerry Ferrara, Arturo Castro, Taylor Hill, Alex Moffat, Eva Victor and Yedoye Travis had joined the cast of the film, with Jonah Feingold directing from a screenplay he wrote.[4]
Principal photography began in October 2019.[5] The film was shot in New York at 22 locations in 15 days.[6]

Release[edit]
The film had its world premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival on June 13, 2021.[7] Prior to the festival, IFC Films acquired distribution rights to the film.[8] It was released in theaters by IFC Films on September 10, 2021.[9]

Reception[edit]
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 41% of 22 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.3/10.[10] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 42 out of 100 based on six critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".[11]
